title: LSE DS105M - Fundamentals of Data Science
text:
ğŸ¯ Learning Objectives

Understand the basic structure of data types and common data formats
Show familiarity with international standards for common data types
Manage a typical data acquisition, cleaning, structuring, and analysis workflow using practical examples
Clean data, and diagnose common problems involved in data corruption and how to fix them
Understand the concept and fundamentals of databases
Link data from different sources
Use the collaboration and version control system GitHub, based on the git version control system.
Markup Language (XML), and the Markdown format for formatting documents and web pages.
Create and maintain simple websites using HTML and CSS
Use APIs to send and retrieve data from Internet sources

Intro





Â Â Â Â Lecture:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Introduction and key tools for data scientists.Â Â Â Â Lab:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  No class this week. Use this time to revisit basic R or python programming
ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 01


Theme: Behind the scenes



Â Â Â Â Lecture:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Terminal: navigating the command line.Â Â Â Â Lab:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Navigating the command line in your own computer
ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 02


Â Â Â Â Lecture:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Cloud: accessing and getting data in and out.Â Â Â Â Lab:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Connecting to the cloud via the command lineÂ Â Â Â Summative 01 (worth 10%):Â Â Â Â Â - Problem set involving the upload of data to the cloud.Â Â Â Â Â - Deadline: day before next weekâ€™s class
ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03


Â Â Â Â Lecture:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Internet: protocols + scrapping + APIs.Â Â Â Â Lab:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Web scraping exerciseÂ Â Â Â Summative 02 (worth 15%):Â Â Â Â Â - Problem set involving web scraping.Â Â Â Â Â - Deadline: day before next weekâ€™s classÂ Â Â Â [Group project]Â Â Â Â Â - after class, students pitch their ideas of preferred APIs/datasetsÂ Â Â Â Â - there will be a designated channel on our Slack for this
ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 04


Theme: Working with data



Â Â Â Â Lecture:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The nature and shape of data (including markup language)Â Â Â Â Lab:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Github & MarkdownÂ Â Â Â [Group project]Â Â Â Â Â - students form groups of 3Â Â Â Â Â - students must submit a team contract to Moodle (not graded)
ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 05


Â Â Â Â Lecture:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Tabular data: dataframes and databasesÂ Â Â Â Lab:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Collaborating as a group on Github
ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 07


Â Â Â Â Lecture:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Unstructured data (text, audio & image)Â Â Â Â Lab:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We will have group presentations instead of a structured class this week.Â Â Â Â Summative 03 (worth 15%):Â Â Â Â Â - each group will present about their selected dataÂ Â Â Â Â - see instructions for marking criteria
ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 08


Â Â Â Â Lecture:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Text as data, regex and sentiment analysisÂ Â Â Â Lab:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Computational Notebooks and DataFrames
ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09


Theme: Applications



Â Â Â Â Lecture:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Topic modelling & document similaritiesÂ Â Â Â Lab:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  ğŸ¦¸ Super tech-supportÂ Â Â Â Â - we will be there to help you sort out any tech problems youâ€™re having with your projects
ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10


Â Â Â Â Lecture:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Data viz with the grammar of graphicsÂ Â Â Â Lab:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We will have group presentations instead of a structured class this week.Â Â Â Â Summative 04 (worth 20%):Â Â Â Â Â - each group will present about their selected dataÂ Â Â Â Â - see instructions for marking criteria
ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 11

title: LSE DS105M | Assessments
text: This course is assessed by a mix of problem sets, group presentation and a final project. You can find the details below:

title: LSE DS105M | Assessments
text:
ğŸ“ Problem Sets (25%)

A mix of coding tasks and elements of self-assessment, similar to problem sets we solve in the weekly labs
Students have until the day before the following class to submit their response to problem sets
Summative problem sets will be released on:

Week 03 - worth 10% of final mark
Week 04 - worth 15% of final mark

title: LSE DS105M | Assessments
text:
ğŸ—£ï¸ Group Presentation (35%)

Students will form groups prior to Reading Week (Week 06)

Pitch your ideas of API/datasets on Week 04
Form the groups on Week 05

Group presentations:

Week 08 - worth 15% of final mark
Week 11 - worth 20% of final mark

title: LSE DS105M | Assessments
text:
ğŸ‡ Final Project (40%)

Each group will have to produce a webpage of their project, using Github Markdown
Description of data, research questions, challenges, statistics and simple plots
Think of it as a portfolio project!
Submission deadline: Lent Term

Exact date to be confirmed
(end of Jan/2023 - beginning of Feb/2023)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 1 - Introduction and the Data Science Toolbox
text:
In this first week, we will cover what you can expect to learn from this course and the course logistics: all you need to know about the structure of the lectures, classes, assessments and how we will interact throughout this course.
We will also cover some of the basics: what do we mean by data science and what tools will you need to use during this course?

title: DS105 Data for Data Scientists
text:
The Data Science Institute





This course is offered by the LSE Data Science Institute (DSI).
DSI is the hub for LSEâ€™s interdisciplinary collaboration in data science




Sign up for DSI events at lse.ac.uk/DSI/Events

title: DS105 Data for Data Scientists
text:
Our courses
DSI offer accessible introductions to Data Science:


DS101
Fundamentals of  Data Science
ğŸ¯ Focus:  theoretical concepts of data science
ğŸ“‚ How:  reflections through reading and writing

DS105
Data for  Data Scientists
ğŸ¯ Focus: collection and handling of real data
ğŸ“‚ How: hands-on coding exercises and a group project

DS202
Data Science for  Social Scientists
ğŸ¯ Focus: fundamental machine learning algorithms
ğŸ“‚ How: practical use of ML techniques and metrics

title: DS105 Data for Data Scientists
text:
Learning Objectives (cont.)
The course will also cover:


workflow management of individual and collaborative data science project
setup and tools for typical data pre-processing (data transformation and data cleaning)

frequently the starting point and most time-consuming part of any data science project.






Check  this link  for a more comprehensive set of learning objectives.

title: DS105 Data for Data Scientists
text:
Structure of lectures ğŸ‘¨ğŸ»â€ğŸ«
Our lectures will be split in two parts:


Part I (~ 50 min): Traditional exposition of theoretical content
break (~ 10 min): Grab coffee â˜• or relax ğŸ§˜
Part II (~ 50 min): Live demo

Typically, demonstration of terminal usage or Jupyter notebooks
Feel free to follow along in your own laptops.

title: DS105 Data for Data Scientists
text:
Structure of classes ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’»


Students will work on weekly, structured problem sets in the staff-led class sessions.
Tips to get the most of classes:

Bring your own laptops ğŸ’» (most tablets are not suitable for programming)
Read the recommended reading prior to the class
Attempt to replicate the examples demonstrated in the live demo during the lecture

title: DS105 Data for Data Scientists
text:
Office hours


It is probably a good idea to book office hours if:

you struggled with a technical or theoretical aspect of a problem set in the previous week,
you have queries about careers in data science,
you want guidance in how to apply data science to other things you are studying outside this course.

Come prepared. You only have 15 minutes.
Ask for help sooner rather than later.
Book slots via StudentHub up to 12 hours in advance.

title: DS105 Data for Data Scientists
text:
Communication


Join our Slack group:  add link to slack
Use the public Slack channels to talk to share links, content (or memes) with your colleagues.
Our teaching team will dedicate some time during the week to answer questions or other interactions on Slack.
Reserve ğŸ“§ e-mail for formal requests: extensions, deferrals, etc.

No need to e-mail to inform you will skip a class, for example.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 01 - Part II  Data Science toolbox
text:
Data science isâ€¦


â€œ[â€¦] a field of study and practice that involves the collection, storage, and processing of data in order to derive important ğŸ’¡ insights into a problem or a phenomenon.




Such data may be generated by humans (surveys, logs, etc.) or machines (weather data, road vision, etc.),




and could be in different formats (text, audio, video, augmented or virtual reality, etc.).â€




(Shah 2020, chap. 1) - Emphasis and emojis are of my own making.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 01 - Part II  Data Science toolbox
text:
Data Science and Social Science

Content borrowed from ME314 Day 1



Social science: The goal is typically explanation
Data science: The goal is frequently prediction, or data exploration
Many of the same methods are used for both objectives




 Illustrate

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 01 - Part II  Data Science toolbox
text:
Practical examples




DS105 - Data for Data Scientists ğŸ–¥ï¸ ğŸ¤¹



Shah, Chirag. 2020. A Hands-on Introduction to Data Science. Cambridge, United Kingdom ; New York, NY, USA: Cambridge University Press. https://librarysearch.lse.ac.uk/permalink/f/1n2k4al/TN_cdi_askewsholts_vlebooks_9781108673907.



 Give a pratical example of how one would approach the same dataset differently under these two modelling views.
